Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) director Allen Dulles provides suggested modifications to the draft U.S. psychological strategy report with respect to the people of Thailand. The CIA agrees with the Psychological Strategy Board (PSB) that the U.S. must coordinate efforts to activate necessary measures to counter the Communist threat to Southeast Asia, in particular to Thailand.

Background information on issues related to the exchange of telemetry equipment, which allows for the remote measurement and reporting of information of interest to a system designer or operator, in preparation for U.S.-U.S.S.R. Strategic Arms Reductions Talks (START). These arms control negotiations between the U.S. and the Soviet Union are aimed at reducing those two countries\' arsenals of nuclear warheads and of the missiles and bombers capable of delivering such weapons.

[Near East] The Middle East [US goals are to maintain the security of the land Transmittal Memorandum, Adm. B. L. Austin, Dir., Joint Staff, to the Chairman, JCS. Apr. 2, 1956. 1 p. Att: Comments on British Chiefs of Staff Views on Revised Paper of the United States/United Kingdom Staff Paper Entitled, \"Analysis of the Military Problems Involved in Action under the Tripartite Declaration of 1950\" [the JCS in general concurs with British Chiefs of Staff views with the following exceptions: US-UK agreed courses of action should be stated only after a Combined Estimate of the situation has been completed; US has no agreed view as to which side is most likely to begin hostilities]. 3 p. TOP SECRET. Declassified Sept. 5, 1978. Released 1979.

In the event Major General Pak Chung-kuk lets a crew member of the USS PUEBLO attend a closed negotiation meeting between the U.S. and North Korea, Admiral Smith will request his immediate release. If denied, Smith will ask to speak to the crew member privately.

Minutes of the President\'s Special Committee on Disarmament Problems 4/17/56: receive and discuss further comments on the U.S. Draft Working Paper for the First Phase of a Comprehensive Agreement for Disarmament.

[Japan. CINCPAC recommends that US interests are best served by revision of the current US-Japan defense treaty rather than by a mutual security treaty. Japan is not ready to undertake responsibilities for a truly \"mutual\" treaty, and a new treaty would result in greater Japanese demands, which, if met, would be difficult for Congress to accept. The US can agree to come to Japan\'s aid if attacked; maintain some air defense forces in Japan for three to four years if they could be withdrawn in an emergency; consult with Japan over US forces based in Japan providing Japan has no veto over their use; note, but not be bound by, the views of the Japanese government with respect to atomic weapons; establish a ten-year expiration date for the treaty; and use its forces in Japan in accordance with the principles of the UN Charter.] CINCPAC, Message No. 4335, to JCS. Aug. 19, 1958. 13 p. TOP SECRET. Declassified June 29, 1979. Released 1981.
